Bƒôdziesz widzieƒá na ekranie tajemnicze s≈Çowa typu "execution error" albo "XYZ is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable program". Nie bƒôdziesz wiedzieƒá czym siƒô r√≥≈ºni Node.js od React.js. I to jest okej. Uwierz mi: w ko≈Ñcu wszystko zrozumiesz. Potrzebujesz czasu i wprawy, a zrozumienie przyjdzie naturalnie.

Po drugie, ucz siƒô publicznie. Graj z innymi w otwarte karty; m√≥w, ≈ºe nie wiesz, nie rozumiesz, nie umiesz. Nie r√≥b z siebie ofiary i nie podkre≈õlaj swojej niewiedzy na ka≈ºdym kroku. Nie przyjmuj postawy defensywnej. Nie przybieraj maski wyuczonej bezradno≈õci. Nie sta≈Ñ siƒô osobƒÖ bezradnƒÖ. entry.title: Interview with Mateusz Barszcz
entry.summary: Our guest today is Mateusz Barszcz,
entry.content:
Our guest today is Mateusz Barszcz, a Chief Software Technical Writer at Hitachi Energy in Krakow, Poland. Let's hear his story, this time in English. For the Polish version, click here. In this interview, you will learn about his extensive experience in technical writing and how technical writing is like competitive sports. Mateusz shares his invaluable observations and insights, which will be helpful for those who want to get started with technical communication, and also for anyone else interested in it.

Introduction‚Äã

Hi, thank you for agreeing to this interview. To start, could you tell us something about yourself?‚Äã

My name is Mateusz Barszcz, and I work at Hitachi Energy, where I create technical documentation. I have been a member of the Technical Writers team since late 2022, when I joined as a Senior Technical Writer. Initially, I worked on a smaller project called Network Manager Wide Area Monitoring System (WAMS), a backend solution for monitoring the state of the power grid.

Currently, I‚Äôm involved in a much larger project with five development teams engaged in the process, serving as the lead technical writer. In that role, I create the documentation plan and ensure we have all the essential information needed to proceed with writing. As a writer, I write user documentation for our internal teams and the end customers receiving the solution. These documents include installation guides, functional descriptions, and release notes. I also support the creation of engineering documentation that lives alongside the code, such as administration guides or readme files.

How would you summarize the essence of the role of a technical writer or technical communication specialist?‚Äã

For me, it is mainly the role of a technical translator. It is a person who gathers information from an engineer or engineers. The engineer‚Äôs statements can be emotional, full of jargon, or incomplete. The technical writer translates this information into a universally understandable language, helping to achieve the user‚Äôs goals. The essential elements of technical writing are understanding the technical context, translating it into comprehensible language, and logically arranging the content.

Career before Hitachi Energy‚Äã

How long have you worked in a technical writer role?‚Äã

Recently, while browsing LinkedIn, I was reminded that I started my technical career 15 years ago, during which I took on various roles. My tasks have always been related to technical content that included visuals. I have been strictly involved in technical writing since 2010. I have created e-learning materials for over three years. As a contractor at Google, for six years I had the opportunity to work in a role that combined both these areas.

How did you become a technical writer?‚Äã

It‚Äôs an interesting story because, after graduation, I had part-time jobs and was wondering what to do next. In 2010, I found a contractor job posting for a so-called junior one-year assignment at Motorola Solutions. They were looking for someone without experience, and as I read the job description, which I accidentally came across, I researched what a technical writer does, and it intrigued me a lot. I have a technical education; I have always liked playing with technology. What prompted me to become a technical writer was the fact that I‚Äôm bilingual. I‚Äôm a native speaker of English and Polish and have technical skills, so these two aspects helped me fit into the role. I applied to Motorola Solutions, completed the recruitment process, and got the role. That was my beginning.

So, by reading this offer, you were building awareness of who a technical writer is.‚Äã

I was building that awareness. I was one of those people who had instructions in their hands many times but never thought about who wrote them and who was responsible for creating them. It was only then that this world began to open up to me. I started discovering it, as initially I was unaware of the people and teams responsible for this documentation. I also did not know at all that documentation was a large area requiring dedicated roles and expertise. In the end, it drew me in.

What projects have you been involved in, and what experiences have you gained?‚Äã

What I like about my career is that it has been dynamic from the very beginning. My responsibilities frequently expanded or evolved, so I couldn‚Äôt complain about stagnation. I started with Motorola Solution products related to radio infrastructure. Several technical writers were responsible for the system's features. After two years, I started describing radio devices mounted in police cars, which allowed me to learn another aspect of radio communication.

A police radio device in a police car similar to the one Mateusz dealt with. Link to the original photo. Author: Government of Prince Edward Island.

Then, I wrote training materials for e-learning, which involved managing content in a different format. I created materials for self-paced learning and instructor-led training about the radio infrastructure I learned initially. I was managing well-known content in a different format. As an instructional designer, I designed trainings for enablement and business topics. The scope of content I operated on changed dynamically.

Then, I accepted an offer to work as a contractor at Google. I joined a small team writing technical content and creating online training for internal project management products. It was a new and completely unknown area for me. I needed to learn many tools designed for employees. It was a dynamic role which I spent over six years in. As the product portfolio developed, my responsibilities expanded. Ultimately, the contracted project ended, and I had to look for something new.

Career at Hitachi Energy‚Äã

Let‚Äôs return to your current role at Hitachi Energy. How is your work organized?‚Äã

Teams work based on the Scrum methodology. The products I work on are new, so we create documents and processes related to their creation from scratch. Since I joined the project, I started working on large documents. My daily work does not strictly fit into the team‚Äôs sprints. I sometimes get tasks to supplement or review engineering documentation. Although my tasks are loosely related to sprints, I‚Äôm bound by deadlines for delivering the product with documentation. I attend project meetings to achieve that, so I frequently contact the team.

What type of documents do you create?‚Äã

I create highly technical installation guides and functional descriptions. These documents often include instructions for the end user who wants to know how to set up the backend of the feature or product. Another aspect that I cover is a description of product operations, such as calculations of current changes, phase shifts of voltages, and deviations in readings. These topics are so complex that I feel like I‚Äôm writing a doctoral thesis. I also create smaller documents, such as release notes.

What tools do you use, and what do you think about them?‚Äã

I work with various tools depending on the needs. Initially, I used Word ‚Äì mainly because it allowed collaboration on the document with the engineers. Still, I‚Äôm not a fan of this tool due to problems with style templates, formatting, and sometimes loss of content. I try to use it as little as possible.

Currently, when I have gathered the content and want to publish the material, I work in Markdown and MadCap Flare. MadCap Flare is excellent, although learning it takes some time and effort. However, once you master the basics, prepare style templates, and set up the work environment, the tool becomes very user-friendly. Nevertheless, I enjoy working in Markdown the most. I can synchronize the content with the repository and do anything I want with it. I can publish a website or import it into MadCap Flare. I have developed an import process that I‚Äôm satisfied with due to its flexibility. Markdown‚Äôs advantages are its simplicity and the content being created in an environment familiar to developers.

How do you gather the information needed to create documentation?‚Äã

I ask people and remind them that I need information for the documents. Engineers are willing to contribute to the documentation. They are often necessary links for creating documentation because I do not understand certain aspects. As a technical writer, I constantly learn about technology and products, and eventually, I become an expert. This reduces the amount of involvement needed from engineers as the project advances.

However, in the beginning, new technologies used in the product require more reliance on what someone tells me. Initially, my task is to piece it together into sentences and achieve the appropriate order of information to get the message across. Sometimes, I find content in repositories that I later include in my documentation. Such discoveries give me great satisfaction.

What is your superpower as a technical writer?‚Äã

I write witty e-mails that are acceptable in a corporate environment. This skill comes in handy both in technical writing and daily communication.

What are the biggest challenges you face in your work?‚Äã

Sometimes, you must convince someone that the path you propose is correct and make it clear to someone that they might not be right themselves. It is not pleasant to impose your opinion on someone. Still, there are specific standards to maintain, and it is necessary. Occasionally, you also have to remind engineers about delivering input. Everyone is busy, and in such cases, one-on-one meetings work well.

What do you like most about your job?‚Äã

I like our Technical Writing team. In the beginning, there were only a few of us, and now the team is growing rapidly and is very diverse. I will compliment our team leader, Piotrek Sroka. I really like his approach to team management. Another thing is the technology in which the project is created and the openness of the development team to new techniques. This team proposes interesting solutions that can be built on Markdown.

Interests‚Äã

What are your interests outside of documentation and technology?‚Äã

My passions are traveling, reading (sci-fi especially), automotive, and cooking. Recipes also relate to instructions.

Speaking of cooking, when you buy new household appliances, such as a food processor, do you go with the flow and spontaneously start using it, or do you read the entire manual from cover to cover?‚Äã

I go with the flow because I prefer to try something out. My memory retention is better if I use something practically or possibly break it üòâ. When needed, I reach for the manual, and then I read it from cover to cover.

What are your interests related to technology and science?‚Äã

I have always been fascinated by science, astronomy, and engineering topics, such as how something is constructed, types of car engines, and the like. I like reading articles about quantum physics and other scientific issues in the New Scientist. It relaxes me and keeps my mind curious about the world.

Well-being‚Äã

How do you maintain peace of mind and a broad smile as a technical writer? How do you achieve zen?‚Äã

Sometimes, switching to another task helps me. If I feel stuck, I try to focus on another part of the task that gives me pleasure or allows for quick success. It is also important not to try to do 100 percent of everything that can be done. After releasing the material, there may be something to improve. It is better to release something 80-90 percent ready and make corrections later.

Everyone has better and worse days; do you have any insights on what can be done to feel better at work? Or are there things to avoid?‚Äã

When I face a task that overwhelms me, sometimes the fact that there are tasks to choose from helps me. Writer‚Äôs block is a real thing. Sometimes, I like to set aside a problematic task and focus on something else that gives me joy, such as working on graphics or the content import process. Playing with techniques or things that are not my primary task relieves the mind. For a while, I do not feel the pressure of time, which calms me down, and after a moment I continue with the previously started thread.

One realizes that documentation is iterative.‚Äã

A principle says the last 10 percent of perfecting the material can take 90 percent of the time. It is about refining details. Where 10-20 percent of your efforts generate 80 percent of the gains, the rest is less important. Focusing on the key issues is crucial. [It‚Äôs about the Pareto principle]. Sometimes, it is good to leave some room for later improvements. The rules that apply in technical writing can be observed even in sports. The best athletes fight for tenths and hundredths of a second, and the effort they have to make to achieve them takes years of hard work.

Yes, it is years of hard work, but every athlete does not exert maximum effort daily. They spread it out so that they also train at moderate intensity and rest to do something big at the very end. Sometimes, we only think about moments of maximum effort, but to get there, they also had to train at low intensity and rest.‚Äã

It is worth thinking long-term. It is not easy, and it may be against our nature because we focus on what is happening now, but seeing the longer perspective can help.

Advice for beginners‚Äã

What advice can you give people who want to start their adventure with writing documentation?‚Äã

I recommend familiarizing yourself with some standards and style guides, working on templates, tackling the description of a technical topic, and sharing this work. You need a portfolio to start the conversation during UX writing and UX design recruitment. In technical writing, I do not encounter this very often. Usually, candidates do not have a sample showing how someone thinks and approaches the documentation. I recommend trying your hand and posting samples on the Internet (for example, on GitHub or your website) to showcase your knowledge of technology, share this work, and take pride in it.

Also, do not worry about not being an English major. I know many people in the industry with various backgrounds, such as biologists or theater studies‚Äô graduates. It is worth seeing how you feel about it if it interests you. The work of a technical writer is primarily based on contact with people, so it is also worth getting involved in some technical writing or engineering environments where you can try your hand at communication and extracting information that is used later. It is worth, for example, being interested in events like hackathons or various meetups, where you can network with new people and get familiar with technical language.

The last question‚Äã

Do you have room for professional development at Hitachi Energy?‚Äã

Definitely yes! This company motivates employees to develop and take on new challenges. I take part in many training sessions, including technical and soft skills. We have the freedom to try new solutions and take on more tasks. Such involvement does not go unnoticed; I‚Äôm probably a good example. Starting in January, I was promoted from Senior Technical Writer to Chief Software Technical Writer (equivalent to Principal Technical Writer).

Congratulations on the well-deserved promotion! And thank you for sharing your thoughts.

Reuse wydaje siƒô byƒá ≈öwiƒôtym Graalem technical writingu, ale w tym artykule chcia≈Çbym pokazaƒá, jak ta popularna praktyka mo≈ºe zepsuƒá wyniki wyszukiwania.

Na przyk≈Çad, tworzymy dokumentacjƒô do pralek. Nasze pralki to 12 modeli, z kt√≥rych ka≈ºdy ma od 5 do 30 funkcji. Podstawowe 5 funkcji jest dostƒôpne w ka≈ºdej pralce a pozosta≈Çe to misterna mozaika powtarzajƒÖcych siƒô lub unikalnych funkcji w r√≥≈ºnych wariantach. U≈ºywamy wiƒôc systemu, kt√≥ry pozwoli nam opisaƒá ka≈ºdƒÖ funkcjƒô raz, a potem posk≈Çadaƒá ksiƒÖ≈ºeczki z kawa≈Çk√≥w tre≈õci jak z klock√≥w. Ka≈ºdy reusowany fragment to klocek tego samego typu.

Gdzie siƒô sprawdza?‚Äã

Takie rozwiƒÖzanie ≈õwietnie siƒô sprawdza kiedy przygotowujemy ksiƒÖ≈ºeczki do druku, bo ka≈ºda z nich zawiera komplet informacji. Niczego w niej nie brakuje. Jednocze≈õnie nie ma w niej informacji o funkcjach, kt√≥re sƒÖ niedostƒôpne w naszym modelu pralki.

Ten spos√≥b publikacji jest tak powszechny, ≈ºe wrƒôcz niezauwa≈ºalny dla u≈ºytkownika ko≈Ñcowego. Co wskazuje na to, ≈ºe sprawdza siƒô bardzo dobrze.

Dlaczego psuje wyszukiwanie?‚Äã

Wyobra≈∫my sobie, ≈ºe instrukcje do pralek sƒÖ teraz dostƒôpne online. Zosta≈Çy wrzucone na portal z dokumentacjƒÖ jako podstrony. Ka≈ºda ksiƒÖ≈ºeczka ma nawigacjƒô po lewej i jest w pe≈Çni kompletnym mini portalem ze wszystkim, czego potrzebuje u≈ºytkownik danego modelu.

Je≈ºeli jednƒÖ z podstawowych funkcji ka≈ºdej pralki jest p≈Çukanie, to na naszym portalu mamy stronkƒô o p≈Çukaniu powt√≥rzonƒÖ 12 razy. Je≈ºeli u≈ºytkownik wpisze w wyszukiwarkƒô "p≈Çukanie" to te 12 stron bƒôdzie konkurowaƒá o jego uwagƒô.

Byƒá mo≈ºe opr√≥cz strony o tytule "P≈Çukanie" jest nastƒôpna, na przyk≈Çad "Problemy z p≈Çukaniem" albo "Kod b≈Çƒôdu: p≈Çukanie", ale u≈ºytkownik ich tak ≈Çatwo nie znajdzie, bo bƒôdƒÖ du≈ºo ni≈ºej albo nawet na drugiej czy trzeciej stronie z wynikami. Poza tym ka≈ºda bƒôdzie w dwunastu kopiach.

Wiƒôc w tym wypadku to, co dobre dla drukowania jest niedobre dla wy≈õwietlania w internecie.

Jak rozwiƒÖzaƒá ten problem?‚Äã

Pr√≥bowa≈Çem znale≈∫ƒá jakie≈õ przyk≈Çady opisujƒÖce ten problem. Mia≈Çem nadziejƒô znale≈∫ƒá jakie≈õ pomys≈Çy na jego rozwiƒÖzanie. Niestety, nie uda≈Ço mi siƒô. Byƒá mo≈ºe takie artyku≈Çy gdzie≈õ istniejƒÖ, ale w moich wyszukiwaniach znajdowa≈Çem tylko reklamy narzƒôdzi, kt√≥re pomagajƒÖ organizowaƒá reuse.

W kolejnych sekcjach opisujƒô rozwiƒÖzania, kt√≥re stosowa≈Çem do tej pory w swojej pracy. Do ka≈ºdego dodajƒô komentarz wynikajƒÖcy z do≈õwiadczenia.

Publikowanie strony tylko raz‚Äã

Najprostsze rozwiƒÖzanie to opublikowaƒá ka≈ºdƒÖ stronƒô tylko raz. Wtedy pojawi siƒô ona w wynikach tylko jeden raz i bƒôdzie jƒÖ ≈Çatwiej spozycjonowaƒá. Poza tym u≈ºytkownik bƒôdzie mia≈Ç mniej problem√≥w z przeglƒÖdaniem wynik√≥w wyszukiwania.

Ja osobi≈õcie widzƒô dwa sposoby na osiƒÖgniƒôcie tego celu. Przybli≈ºƒô je na przyk≈Çadzie dokument√≥w w formacie DITA, ale to samo odnosi siƒô do innych generatorow stron statycznych.

Bez reusu‚Äã

Pierwszy to konstruowaƒá nasze dokumenty tak, ≈ºeby ka≈ºda strona wystƒôpowa≈Ça w nich tylko raz. Je≈ºeli mamy wiele map DITA, kt√≥re tworzƒÖ nasze rozliczne dokumenty, nie mo≈ºemy powtarzaƒá topik√≥w miƒôdzy mapami.

Czyli tworzymy osobne mapy dla ka≈ºdego PDFa i jednƒÖ mapƒô dla naszego portalu HTML. Je≈ºeli sƒÖ jakie≈õ elementy wsp√≥lne, na przyk≈Çad nasza strona o p≈Çukaniu, to umieszczany jƒÖ w mapie dla HTMLa tylko raz. To oznacza, ≈ºe opublikujemy jednƒÖ paczkƒô stron, kt√≥ra opisuje wszystkie mo≈ºliwe funkcje wszystkich modeli pralek. ≈ªeby pom√≥c u≈ºytkownikowi, na ka≈ºdej stronie piszemy do kt√≥rych modeli pralek ta strona siƒô odnosi.

Taka forma publikacji mo≈ºe jednak czasem namieszaƒá u≈ºytkownikowi w g≈Çowie. Mo≈ºe to efektywnie doprowadziƒá do takiej sytuacji jak drukowanie jednej instrukcji dla wszystkich modeli pralek i zaznaczanie przy ka≈ºdej funkcji listy modeli, w kt√≥rych jest dostƒôpna. Nie jest to idealne rozwiƒÖzanie, ale dosyƒá czƒôsto spotykane w materia≈Çach drukowanych.

Skoro jeste≈õmy online, to mo≈ºemy daƒá u≈ºytkownikowi przyciski z filtrami, kt√≥re "ukryjƒÖ" strony do "innych modeli". Ale to wymaga od naszych u≈ºytkownik√≥w g≈Çƒôbokiej znajomo≈õci naszych produkt√≥w i eksperckiego podej≈õcia do korzystania z naszej strony (power user!). A to z kolei nie jest co≈õ, czego powinni≈õmy wymagaƒá od naszych u≈ºytkownik√≥w.

Single sourcing‚Äã

Drugi to przetwarzaƒá mapy DITA inaczej dla druku (PDF) a inaczej do internetu (HTML). Dla PDFa, powtarzamy tƒô stronƒô w ka≈ºdej mapie, kt√≥ra jej potrzebuje. Z tego powstajƒÖ oczywi≈õcie osobne PDFy i powtarzajƒÖca siƒô strona nie przeszkadza u≈ºytkownikowi.

Natomiast dla HTMLa u≈ºywamy warunk√≥w w mapie, kt√≥re nie powtarzajƒÖ tej strony tylko umieszczajƒÖ link do niej. Czyli wygenerujemy osobnƒÖ paczkƒô stron dla ka≈ºdego modelu, ale w ≈ºadnej paczce nie bƒôdzie naszej strony o p≈Çukaniu. Ta bƒôdzie w osobnej paczce zawierajƒÖcej wszystkie funkcje wsp√≥lne.

<topicref href="plukanie.dita" platform="print" />
<reltable>
  <relheader>
    <relcolspec type="task"/>
    <relcolspec type="reference"/>
  </relheader>
  <relrow>
    <relcell>
      <topicref href="plukanie.dita"/>
    </relcell>
    <relcell linking="targetonly">

</reltable>

To trochƒô karko≈Çomne rozwiƒÖzanie, ale powinno zadzia≈Çaƒá. W tym przyk≈Çadzie, topicref kierujƒÖcy do plukanie.dita pojawi siƒô tylko je≈õli akurat budujemy PDFa a nie pojawi siƒô w HTMLu.

reltable i zawarty w niej atrybut linking="targetonly" sprawi, ≈ºe na stronie "U≈ºyteczne linki" pojawi siƒô link do "P≈Çukanie", ale nie odwrotnie.

BONUS: magiczna technologia‚Äã

Trzeci, magiczny spos√≥b to u≈ºyƒá mechanizmu publikacji, kt√≥ry wykracza poza typowe generowanie stron statycznych. Nie mo≈ºemy polegaƒá na prostym transformowaniu mapy DITA na strony HTML. Zamiast tego musimy zbudowaƒá system, kt√≥ry w jaki≈õ spos√≥b posortuje z zdeduplikuje nasze strony.

Taki system to nie lada wyzwanie i nie sƒÖdzƒô, ≈ºeby taki gdziekolwiek istnia≈Ç. Przynajmniej ja takiego jeszcze nie widzia≈Çem, chocia≈º mo≈ºliwe, ≈ºe wkr√≥tce rozpoczniemy nad nim pracƒô w moim obecnym zespole. Je≈ºeli to siƒô uda, to postaram siƒô podzieliƒá ze ≈õwiatem naszym osiƒÖgniƒôciem.

Filtrowanie‚Äã

Je≈õli nie mo≈ºemy publikowaƒá stron tylko raz, kolejnƒÖ najlepszƒÖ opcjƒÖ jest filtrowanie. Dodajmy po lewej stronie panel z checkboxami i pozw√≥lmy u≈ºytkownikowi wybraƒá, o kt√≥rej wersji pralki chce poczytaƒá. To nie jest idealne rozwiƒÖzanie, bo o ile w wypadku pralki, u≈ºytkownik prawdopodobnie wie jaki model posiada, o tyle w bardziej skomplikowanych systemach wybory filtr√≥w stajƒÖ siƒô trudniejsze. Mo≈ºe doj≈õƒá do tego, ≈ºe u≈ºytkownik nie bƒôdzie wiedzia≈Ç jaki "produkt" wybraƒá, ani co mamy na my≈õli rozr√≥≈ºniajƒÖc "wersjƒô" od "wydania". Albo czym siƒô r√≥≈ºni "komponent" od "czƒô≈õci".

Kolaps‚Äã

Ostatnie rozwiƒÖzanie, kt√≥re widzia≈Çem w akcji, to zgrupowanie podobnych wynik√≥w. Czyli jeden wynik o tytule "P≈Çukanie" a pod spodem zwijany akordeon z listƒÖ innych wersji strony o p≈Çukaniu.

To rozwiƒÖzanie ma swoje s≈Çabe strony. na przyk≈Çad to, ≈ºe rozwijana sekcja mo≈ºe staƒá siƒô bardzo d≈Çuga i przez to ma≈Ço pomocna. Je≈ºeli spr√≥bujemy jƒÖ wyposa≈ºyƒá w jakie≈õ kontrolki pozwalajƒÖce wybraƒá model pralki, to znacznie zwiƒôkszymy jej poziom skomplikowania.

Innym problemem jest to, ≈ºe u≈ºytkownicy mogƒÖ nie zrozumieƒá co daje ta sekcja i jak jej powinni u≈ºywaƒá. Dla nas jest oczywiste, ≈ºe sƒÖ w niej wymienione wszystkie inne instancje tej samej strony w innych modelach pralki. Ale to co dla nas jest oczywiste wynika z tego, ze znamy strukturƒô w≈Çasnej dokumentacji.

Generalnie to rozwiƒÖzanie nie jest absolutnie najgorsze. Warto go spr√≥bowaƒá i zebraƒá feedback od u≈ºytkownik√≥w.

Nie ma z≈Çotego ≈õrodka‚Äã

Poradzenie sobie z tym problemem na pewno bƒôdzie wymaga≈Ço g≈Çƒôbokiej analizy i dostosowania siƒô do wymaga≈Ñ u≈ºytkownika. Nie bƒôdziemy w stanie znale≈∫ƒá uniwersalnego rozwiƒÖzania dla ka≈ºdego zbioru dokumentacji. Wiƒôc je≈ºeli kto≈õ twierdzi, ≈ºe ma uniwersalne rozwiƒÖzanie, podejd≈∫my do niego z odrobinƒÖ rezerwy.

Kariera przed do≈ÇƒÖczeniem do zespo≈Çu Hitachi Energy‚Äã

Jak d≈Çugo trwa twoja kariera techniczna?‚Äã

Szukali tzw. juniora, czyli kogo≈õ bez do≈õwiadczenia, a mnie w miarƒô czytania tego og≈Çoszenia bardzo zainteresowa≈Ço, czym zajmuje siƒô technical writer. Mam wykszta≈Çcenie techniczne, zawsze lubi≈Çem bawiƒá siƒô technologiami. Dodatkowo moja dwujƒôzyczno≈õƒá ‚Äì jestem native speaker'em angielskiego i polskiego.
